docs.abstract: Elizabeth Warren and Pete Buttigieg are among the presidential candidates earning approval from the government-reform group End Citizens United.
docs.snippet: Elizabeth Warren and Pete Buttigieg are among the presidential candidates earning approval from the government-reform group End Citizens United.
docs.lead_paragraph: Seven Democratic presidential candidates, including Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Ind., have promised that their first legislation as president would be an ambitious clean-government bill, earning their campaigns an influential reform group’s stamp of approval.

headline.main: Seven 2020 Democrats Pledge to Focus First Bill on Fighting Corruption

docs.abstract: In areas like Sugar Land, Tex., a burgeoning multiethnic population and suburbanites repelled by President Trump are giving Democrats more hope.
docs.snippet: In areas like Sugar Land, Tex., a burgeoning multiethnic population and suburbanites repelled by President Trump are giving Democrats more hope.
docs.lead_paragraph: SUGAR LAND, Tex. — Nearly 700 miles from the El Paso Walmart where the suspect in the killing of 22 people on Saturday denounced a “Hispanic invasion,” Rish Oberoi, a candidate for state representative, gestured toward a bustling dining room in a popular Vietnamese restaurant and marveled at the diversity of this Houston suburb.

headline.main: How the El Paso Shooting Exposes the Rifts in Texas Politics
headline.print_headline: Changing Face of Texas Nudges State’s Politics More to the Left

byline.original: By Jonathan Martin and Matt Flegenheimer

docs.abstract: The CNN debate was a clash over health care with moderates along the edge throwing firebombs on the electability of progressives with the boldest policy plans.
docs.snippet: The CNN debate was a clash over health care with moderates along the edge throwing firebombs on the electability of progressives with the boldest policy plans.
docs.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — It was one of the most substantive presidential primary debates in recent memory, and the two Democratic candidates with the most ambitious plans dominated the stage.

headline.main: 6 Highlights From Night 1 of the July Democratic Debates

byline.original: By Lisa Lerer, Reid J. Epstein, Shane Goldmacher and Katie Glueck

docs.abstract: During the Democratic debate, Mayor Pete Buttigieg and Gov. Steve Bullock both spoke in stark terms about how the epidemic of gun violence had personally affected them.
docs.snippet: During the Democratic debate, Mayor Pete Buttigieg and Gov. Steve Bullock both spoke in stark terms about how the epidemic of gun violence had personally affected them.
docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Pete Buttigieg and Gov. Steve Bullock on Tuesday night both spoke in stark terms about how the epidemic of gun violence had personally affected them.

headline.main: Pete Buttigieg on Gun Violence: ‘I Was Part of the First Generation That Saw Routine School Shootings’

docs.abstract: The front-runners, Joe Biden and Kamala Harris, didn’t exactly flop. But they were outshined by Cory Booker.
docs.snippet: The front-runners, Joe Biden and Kamala Harris, didn’t exactly flop. But they were outshined by Cory Booker.
docs.lead_paragraph: Tuesday night’s debate belonged to the front-runners, Senators Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren. But their counterparts on Wednesday, Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Senator Kamala Harris, couldn’t quite replicate their dominance.

headline.main: Who Won Night 2 of the Democratic Debate? Experts Weigh In

docs.abstract: Lower-polling candidates had their moments, but none outshone the front-runners, Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren.
docs.snippet: Lower-polling candidates had their moments, but none outshone the front-runners, Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren.
docs.lead_paragraph: Those hoping for an underdog candidate to run away with Tuesday night’s debate did not get their wish. The winners — at least in the initial assessment — were the night’s two front-runners, Senators Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren.

headline.main: Who Won Night 1 of the Democratic Debate? Experts Weigh In

docs.abstract: At the Democratic debates in a humid Motor City, it wasn’t just the candidates who were on display and clamoring for attention.
docs.snippet: At the Democratic debates in a humid Motor City, it wasn’t just the candidates who were on display and clamoring for attention.
docs.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Nearly everyone agreed: The bathrooms were a problem.

headline.main: The Debates in Detroit: A Big Field, a Sprawling Circus and Lots of Porta Potties

byline.original: By Lisa Lerer and Reid J. Epstein

docs.abstract: In an extended interview, the California senator explains why she thinks litmus-test questions aren’t helpful and how she is approaching this campaign.
docs.snippet: In an extended interview, the California senator explains why she thinks litmus-test questions aren’t helpful and how she is approaching this campaign.
docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Kamala Harris has emerged as one of the most important candidates in the Democratic primary, besting Joseph R. Biden Jr. in a debate last month and exciting liberal voters who see her as a strong challenger to President Trump. But Ms. Harris has eluded ideological definition for much of the race.

headline.main: What Kamala Harris Doesn’t Want to Be Asked at the Debate

docs.abstract: He’s an entrepreneur and former tech executive who wants to give Americans $12,000 a year. Here’s some background.
docs.snippet: He’s an entrepreneur and former tech executive who wants to give Americans $12,000 a year. Here’s some background.
docs.lead_paragraph: Andrew Yang, 44, is participating on Thursday in the second Democratic presidential primary debate. Mr. Yang is a political neophyte and former tech executive with a devoted internet following known as the “Yang Gang.” As he has traveled across the country, running what he has called the “nerdiest presidential campaign in history,” he has unabashedly embraced his Taiwanese-American background.

headline.main: Andrew Yang on Universal Basic Income

docs.abstract: In a contentious exchange during the last round of Democratic debates, Ms. Harris confronted Mr. Biden about having worked with segregationists in the Senate and discussed her personal history with busing. Here’s a refresher.
docs.snippet: In a contentious exchange during the last round of Democratic debates, Ms. Harris confronted Mr. Biden about having worked with segregationists in the Senate and discussed her personal history with busing. Here’s a refresher.
docs.lead_paragraph: Perhaps no moment from the first Democratic debates in June was more dramatic than the tense exchange between former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Senator Kamala Harris of California. The two Democrats sparred on the issues of race, segregation and school busing.

headline.main: When Kamala Harris and Joe Biden Clashed on Busing and Segregation
